summary: This document is a U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) approval notice for an H-1B work visa petition filed by Jeffrey Epstein for Ghislaine Maxwell. It approves her petition to work for Epstein as a nonimmigrant worker from November 5, 1992, to November 4, 1995, with visa processing directed through the U.S. consulate in London.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Filed the I-129 petition for a nonimmigrant worker (H-1B visa) for Ghislaine Maxwell. Listed as the chairman at 457 Madison Ave, New York, NY.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The beneficiary of the approved H-1B work visa petition filed by Jeffrey Epstein. Her full name is listed as Ghislaine Noelle Marion Maxwell, a citizen of France.

connections.description: Epstein petitioned for Maxwell to obtain an H-1B work visa to be employed by him, establishing a formal employer-employee relationship as recognized by U.S. immigration authorities.

events.title: H-1B Visa Petition Approval
events.description: The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service approves Jeffrey Epstein's I-129 petition for Ghislaine Maxwell to obtain an H-1B nonimmigrant work visa.

locations: 457 Madison Ave 4th FL, New York, NY 10022 (Jeffrey Epstein's business address)
London, UK (Designated U.S. consulate for visa processing)
Saint Albans, VT 05479-0001 (Address of the INS Eastern Service Center)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein formally petitioned for Ghislaine Maxwell to obtain an H-1B work visa to be employed by him in the United States.
The visa petition was approved on November 5, 1992, and was valid for three years, until November 4, 1995.
Maxwell's citizenship is listed as France, and the visa processing was directed through the U.S. consulate in London.
The document establishes a formal, government-sanctioned employer-employee relationship between Epstein and Maxwell in the early 1990s.
The approval notice contains standard warnings about unauthorized employment and the requirement to maintain status.
